general.description:
Before coming to the Bar, Tom was the In-house Solicitor at Moonee Valley City Council and the Manager for Properties and Legal Services.  This unique position incorporated the roles of Manager Statutory Planning Enforcement, Manager Property Services and Municipal Building Surveyor.

Prior to becoming a solicitor, Tom worked as a Building Surveyor and Building Inspector in both the private and public sectors and has over 20 years experience with extensive knowledge in advising councils, developers, builders, landowners, objectors and statutory authorities.

Tom regularly appears before the Victorian Civil Administrative Tribunal (VCAT), the Building Appeals Board, the Building Practitioners Board and the Magistrates’ Court on planning and building related matters. 

Tom’s experience includes the following:

VCAT - PLANNING LIST

•	Merits appeals for Councils, objectors, developers and statutory authorities.
•	Planning Enforcement.
•	Declarations and injunctions.
•	Existing use rights.
•	Restrictive covenants.
•	Easements.

VCAT - DOMESTIC BUILDING LIST

•	Domestic building disputes.
•	Mediation.
•	Compulsory conferences.

VCAT – REVIEW & REGULATION LIST

•	Review of Building Practitioners’ Board decisions.

BUILDING APPEALS BOARD

•	Report and Consent (Res Code) reviews.
•	Protection of adjoining property disputes.
•	Building Orders / Building Notices reviews.

BUILDING PRACTITIONERS BOARD

•	Inquests relating to the conduct of building practitioners.

MAGISTRATES’ COURT

•	Appearing for both the prosecution and defence in statutory criminal prosecutions.

OTHER

Tom regularly presents the following courses:

•	Property Law course to trainee solicitors for Leo Cussen Centre of Law.

Tom is also a guest lecturer at:

•	The University of Melbourne for the Law Masters course.
•	Victoria University of Technology for the Environmental Safety and Risk Engineering course.

Director of Geelong Women in Business
general.description:
Samantha Krajina is a serial entrepreneur having founded and invested into a number of businesses, but is most recognized for her work in and the founding of Geelong Women in Business. 

Previously an Accountant, Samantha holds a Bachelor of Business (Accounting) and has a comprehensive knowledge of business as a whole from accounting, PR & marketing, digital, events and more. 

At 17, had created her first business and developed it nationally within it’s first 3 years of operation. Whilst still in Accounting, Samantha and her husband opened the doors as Relationship Specialists and created waves in an otherwise rigid industry. From developing an International award-recognized Dating App, to writing for some of Australia’s largest publications and appearing on mainstream TV as a resident Relationship Expert, Samantha took on the world with all things relationships from those of a personal matter, to the education system to corporate relationship training.

She has an in-depth knowledge of behavioural science through NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming) and is certified in mBIT (Multiple Brain Integration Techniques) as a facilitator. The combination of accounting, business acumen, relationships and psychology mixed with a true entrepreneur confidence and drive, makes Samantha a force to be reckoned with and one to constantly watch.

Geelong Women in Business is continuing to kick goals with Samantha at the forefront, and she has developed and facilitated some of the regions largest and instrumental events including The Geelong Small Business Expo and The Geelong Small Business Awards. Samantha thrives in the event space and feels at home on stage and in front of groups of people facilitating events, teaching at workshops and setting the vibe as an MC whether it be at her own events, as a special guest, or for example, hosting at the Victorian Government’s Small Business Festival. She is also known for her regular segments on local radio station, BayFM 93.9.

jobs.description: Geelong Women in Business is an interactive membership association for women in business in the local Geelong area. We support all women regardless of the life stage, profitability, industry, or even existence of their business and offer a platform to develop, learn and grow. We host events both large and small, facilitate collaborations, manage a directory and offer invaluable knowledge and resources all under one roof. We work alongside organisations that support small businesses and host a program for women who are taking the leap into business to have all of the information and skills they need. We source experts to contribute to our monthly events to bring value from far and wide, and ensure the members are driving the content and developmental direction. The most successful of our events have been the Small Business Festival (put together in 6 weeks with over 70 exhibitors and over 350 attendees) and the Small Business Awards (over 4k people engaged, hundreds of nominations and a sold out Awards Ceremony with celebrity endorsement). We have a committee of incredible women who drive different parts of the business from Events, PR, Creative Direction, Content and more, and have developed an effective, efficient and easy to use process of growing and maintaining the network and database.

jobs.jobTitle: Relationship Expert & Co-Host on Bay 93.9 The Catch Up
jobs.description:
Relationship Expert and regular Co-Host at BayFM 93.9's The Catch Up Show with Daryl
      
      Reader.

With Geelong having its fair share of hits in big business from the likes of Ford, Target and Alcoa, it’s the small businesses in Geelong that are banding together, growing the economy and employing people. There are also many small businesses that may not have a huge audience reach of awareness, but are doing extraordinary things in and for Geelong, that we want to recognize. That’s why we have created The Geelong Small Business Awards, a unique program within the award arena, solely focusing on micro to small businesses. Unlike many awards, we don’t look at financials and measurement of success; we are looking at things like contribution to the community, innovation and collaboration. 

Geelong is home to some of the most creative, innovative and thriving small businesses and we house a great number of dedicated local heroes who support Geelong and it’s tight-knit and loyal community. It's time to bring it all together and give reward and recognition where due, this time focusing on the little guys that are shaping our culture and community. 

The inaugural Geelong Small Business Awards are set to be celebrated on the 23rd of March, 2017 in Geelong. The mission is to provide small business owners the platform to be recognized for their efforts and inspire the continuation, growth and success of local small businesses and aspiring entrepreneurs. We want to showcase the amazing small business community and to open the doors to engage with youth, encouraging the expansion of local business development with the enticement of awards.

www.gsbawards.com.au

For the third year running, Geelong Women In Business is proud to announce the Geelong Business Expo 2018.
It’s imperative that as a flourishing and talented community, we network with each other, collaborate, support and show the community what fantastic local businesses are available to us. The undeniable beauty of Geelong is that we have become an incredibly large town, but no one has told those who reside here. The essence of community, local support and working together is stronger than ever and we are being put on the map in the most extraordinary ways.
We have industry experts, successful entrepreneurs, inspirational stories, future innovators and Geelong’s most talented artists and creators. The culture of Geelong Women In Business and the Small Business Expo Geelong is to fully embrace, connect and share all of the wonderful people doing wonderful things in Geelong.
We are bringing attention to Geelong and Small Business from far and wide. With our PR and Communications team on board and ready to rock and roll, they have every source covered in advertising, marketing and promotional campaigns. The reach we have in Geelong from our own network, supporting networks and media partners, we are set to see high volume attendees and quality exhibitors. Geelong loves a good market, and being that products and services are available to be sold at the event, this is the time to bring out the good stuff!
 
Any enquiries in regards to the event, exhibiting, donating or attending, please don't hesitate to contact us at expo@geelongwomen.com.au

jobs.description:
Zaven Mardirossian is one of Australia’s leading competition and intellectual property lawyers and a litigator, who heads up Arnold Bloch Leibler’s competition practice.

Zaven has a reputation for successfully representing clients facing some of the toughest Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) investigations and prosecutions in the country. His clients include national leaders in manufacturing, retailing, wholesale, on-line and construction. He advises on a wide range of competition and consumer law matters, including mergers and acquisitions, cartel and other anti-competitive conduct, misleading or deceptive conduct, and unfair and unconscionable business practices.

Zaven was first appointed partner in Arnold Bloch Leibler’s litigation & dispute resolution practice in 1998. He graduated from Monash University with a Bachelor of Laws with Honours and a Bachelor of Arts. He has published chapters on national and international antitrust and competition policy and issues, including for Oxford University Press, Berkeley University and Thomson Reuters.

Zaven is a member of the Business Law section (Competition and Consumer Committee) of The Law Council of Australia.

The matters on which I act often relate to the structuring and financing of property or private equity investments but they also relate to distressed or opportunistic plays as well. 

At ABL, we pride ourselves on being trusted advisers to our clients. This is because we not only bring a high degree of technical excellence to our work but also because we are called on to provide advice,  and apply our commercial judgement and acumen to the matters in which we are involved. I very much enjoy being trusted adviser to many of my clients and privileged to perform this role. 

Outside of work, you will often find me exercising at Bondi, enjoying the harbour or running after my children...

general.headline: Partner at Lander & Rogers, Family & Relationship Law (Accredited Family Law Specialist)
general.description:
Stephanie is a Partner within the Family and Relationship Law department at Lander & Rogers and is an Accredited Family Law Specialist.  She was admitted to practice in April 2007 and has been practicing exclusively in Family and Relationship law since that time.  

Her practice includes advising on all aspects of family law and related jurisdictions including complex property and parenting matters, matters pertaining to de facto and same sex couples, spousal maintenance, child support, financial agreements, international family law matters and family violence. Stephanie provides timely, commercial advice and works alongside her clients and other professional advisers to promptly resolve relationship related disputes. 

She has extensive court appearance experience, both as an instructing solicitor and as an advocate.
Stephanie regularly undertakes work involving complex company structures, trusts and tax issues.  Stephanie has represented Applicants and Respondents as well as Third Party Respondents.  Stephanie also regularly provides advice and representation to Trustees in Bankruptcy seeking to intervene in Family Court proceedings.

Stephanie is experienced in drafted complex settlement documents including Orders by Consent, Financial Agreements and Child Support Agreements.

Stephanie's practice also includes several clients who are located overseas in Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, England, and continental Europe. Those files often involve collaboration with family lawyers in those overseas jurisdictions.

Stephanie completed a Master of Laws at the University of Melbourne in 2011.  In that study she undertook subjects pertaining to commercial legal practice as well as Family and Relationship Law. 

Stephanie regularly writes and edits family and relationship law articles.  
She is a member of the Law Institute of Victoria and Victorian Women's Lawyers.

general.headline: Partner at Barry.Nilsson.Lawyers
general.description:
Jane is an Accredited Specialist in Family Law who helps her clients resolve issues relating to children and the division of property and assets, following the breakdown of a marriage or de facto (including same-sex) relationship. Depending on the circumstances, this can involve negotiation/mediation or litigation.

Jane advises clients both in Australia and overseas about separation and prenuptial / cohabitation agreements. She has conducted litigation in Victoria and interstate relating to financial and children’s issues, including relocation.

Jane has chaired CLE conferences for the legal profession, in addition to presenting CLE sessions.  She is an experienced public speaker who has presented to interested industry groups on family law topics, and is available for speaking engagements.

Jane's experience arbitrating child support disputes for the Commonwealth Government means that she is able to understand the challenges confronting a decision maker when arbitrating a family law dispute and how best to ensure that these challenges are addressed on behalf of her clients.

Although Jane is based in Melbourne, she has previously lived and practised in a regional area and this has provided her with local insight into the particular issues that confront separating couples who live in rural areas for example, issues of privacy, the challenges of distance and more limited availability of services and supports.  

Family law disputes can be very stressful for all parties involved.  Wherever possible, resolving disputes swiftly and with dignity promotes better outcomes for families, especially where children are involved.   The preservation of a parenting alliance between separating parents is also key.  Jane is mindful of these objectives when advising her clients and assessing family law matters.

general.headline: Experienced construction lawyer - Lander & Rogers
general.description:
I am a Special Counsel within Lander & Rogers' Commercial Disputes group who acts for commercial and corporate clients predominantly in the Construction and Real-estate sectors. 

I assist with the preparation, negotiation and finalisation of construction contracts and related documentation, and also advise on the administration of projects during construction which includes providing advice in connection with how best to avoid or minimise disputes.

Where disputes ensue which have included claims relating to liquidated damages, latent conditions, defective design and construction, and claims for variations, I provide advice and guidance in managing those disputes.  I am an experienced litigator, having conducted litigation in most jurisdictions and State and Federal Courts. I also practise widely in all forms of dispute resolution, including mediations, security for payment adjudications, expert determinations and arbitrations. 

My approach to resolving disputes is practical and client-focused. I enjoy getting to know my clients and their businesses, as this allows me to provide tailored risk mitigation advice to help them manage their disputes in their infancy and avoid litigation where possible.  Where it is not possible to avoid litigation, I am mindful of my client's key objectives and utilise litigation as a tool to achieve their best possible outcome.

I have completed two in-house secondments with the Water Corporation of Western Australia and AECOM (a global engineering consultancy firm) which has given me a really strong appreciation of both the commercial drivers and the types of issues that my clients regularly face.

general.description:
I am excited to have been appointed Corrs' Diversity and Inclusion Partner and the Chair of Corrs’ Diversity Council.  I am responsible for leading Corrs’ strategy and programs to increase the diversity of our workforce and foster an inclusive culture in which all our people know they are valued members of the team and can boldly contribute to our success and the success of our clients.

In 18 years at Corrs, I have been fortunate to work across a broad range of the firm’s activities in legal practice and strategic business roles.

In 2015/2016, I led the development and start-up of Orbit Legal, a Corrs owned legal resourcing business delivering best practice in-house legal resources to our clients when they need it. 

I was Corrs’ National Pro Bono partner from 2012 to 2016 and in 2007 I worked as a member of the human resources and marketing teams managing strategic change projects.

In over 15 years as a workplace relations lawyer I have advised government and private clients on a broad range of industrial relations and workplace policy matters, managed complex industrial relations litigation and presented workplace training programs to educate boards, employers and employees about equal opportunity, discrimination, sexual harassment and bullying in the workplace.

general.description:
Anyone can tell a tale. Stories are different. 

I help brands turn complex ideas into accessible narratives that engage and persuade the audience they're trying to reach. It might be a renewables provider seeking to increase share of market, a technology startup looking to drive inbound marketing or a professional services firm aiming to raise awareness of its new service.  

It all starts with listening.

I work with senior stakeholders to develop value propositions, elevator statements, brand narratives and the content emanating from this strategic work, pulling customers and employees closer. 

By distilling complex information into accessible and engaging narratives, I’ve helped B2B organisations secure contracts ranging from $1.2 billion to $2.2 billion. In the consumer space,  I've developed campaigns that have seen increases in product consumption by as much as 350%. Responsible for content marketing at Corrs Chambers Westgarth, I have helped raise client engagement; the firm was recently voted #1 across Australia and APAC by clients in Legal 500’s Intelligence Report. 

My work has taken place in Europe, US and Asia Pacific, changing the behaviours of both B2B and B2C audiences across the globe. I have vast experience both agency-side and client-side collaborating with C-suite executives and their teams across professional services firms, leading online trading companies, international manufacturing organisations and global IT consultancies. 

Your company may have lots it wants to say. I can show you what your audience needs to hear.

general.headline: Commercial Property Lawyer, Partner and Board Member at DibbsBarker (retired 2/4/2018)
general.description:
What most appealed to me about becoming a commercial property lawyer at the beginning of my career was the tactile nature of land, bricks and mortar. I was also drawn to the capacity of parties in real estate transactions to work together to achieve mutually beneficial and valuable outcomes.

My main focus for the last four decades has been commercial and industrial leasing. I work with major corporations and listed property trusts in relation to commercial and industrial buildings as well as shopping centres. The natural adjunct has been the acquisition, development and disposal of the buildings in which the leasing business is or is to be carried out. After all, what is being bought or sold is an actual or potential income stream and any due diligence must be primarily concerned with anything which may impact on that income stream. This means that a review of all the existing leases and ancillary documents is critical.

Prudent landlords will require well drafted leases which protect their interests and thereby enhance the capital value of their buildings. Over the years, I have seen innumerable leases and ancillary documents. As such, my clients trust that I know what to look for and that I fully understand the significance of particular terms. They trust that I appreciate that each client and property has its own particularities.

In a slow-growing economy, costs savings take on a particular importance, especially for building owners. On the other hand, tenants are a landlord’s life blood and their requirements need to be managed accordingly. I am pleased to see there now appears to be a trend in streamlining processes to include more balanced leasing documentation, which should lead to costs reductions for both landlords and tenants.

general.headline: Real Estate Partner at Dentons
general.description:
The property market in Australia has evolved significantly over the years. It has grown substantially to be one of Australia’s largest industries and a substantial source of inbound capital. I have seen many new listed and unlisted property players emerge and real estate transactions have become a lot more sophisticated and complex.

The clients I work with appreciate my ‘whole of solution’ approach and the fact that I have been servicing the Australian property market for so many years. That knowledge of the market and its key players allows me to apply legal expertise with commercial common sense to my clients’ property transactions in the most cost efficient and risk-free way.

Over the years, I have had the privilege to recruit, mentor and retain some of the most talented younger generation property lawyers many of whom continue to work in our Property & Projects team.

general.headline: Barrister at Victorian Bar (List A)
general.description:
Andrew has over 15 years' experience practising in intellectual property (including patents), information technology and commercial litigation. He is one of three Melbourne barristers included in Doyle's List of Emerging Intellectual Property & TMT Junior Counsel for 2017.

Before coming to the Bar, Andrew was Special Counsel with Norton Rose Fulbright.  In that role, he managed the successful parallel importation strategy in Paul’s Retail Pty Ltd v Lonsdale Australia Ltd [2012] FCAFC 130.  He acted for Gilead in relation to its hepatitis C drug “Harvoni” (in which he had carriage of Gilead’s expert evidence about mathematical modelling of HCV infections).  Andrew acted for Foo Fighters in the band’s copyright claim regarding the track “Learn to Fly” and, later, for Queens of the Stone Age, in relation to “The Lost Art of Keeping a Secret”.

Andrew has broad litigation expertise, acting for Matthew Joyce throughout the Sunland (Dubai Waterfront) litigation.  

Andrew holds a Bachelor of Laws, Bachelor of Science and Master of Laws (IP) from Murdoch University and a Master of Laws from Cornell Law School, where he was awarded two academic prizes.

Since coming to the Bar, his experience includes:

Directed OE Pty Ltd v OE Solutions Pty Ltd (VID 1157/2017) (with S McNicol QC) (confidential information, search orders, privilege)

CPL Notting Hill Pty Ltd v Microsoft Corporation [2018] FCA 1473 & Microsoft Corporation v CPL Notting Hill [2018] FCCA 2465 (with P Zappia QC) (copyright)

Kraft Foods Group Brands LLC v Bega Cheese Limited (VID 1220/2017) (with R Garrett QC, P Gray QC, IP Horak, M Fleming) (copyright, passing off)

Vokes Ltd v Laminar Air Flow Pty Ltd [2018] FCAFC 109 (with IP Horak) (trade marks, admin law)

Werribee Automotive Holdings Pty Ltd v Volkswagen Group Australia Pty Ltd (S ECI 2017 220 (with JP Moore QC) (franchising, trade marks, freezing orders)

general.headline: Barrister, Victorian Bar; Winner, “Barrister of the Year”, Australian Law Awards 2018 and Women In Law Awards 2017
general.description:
Katherine accepts briefs in all areas of commercial and corporate law. Before coming to the Bar, Katherine was an Associate at the Federal Court of Australia, first to the Honourable Justice Michelle Gordon in 2011, and then to the Honourable Justice John Middleton in 2012 and 2013.  Prior to that Katherine was a solicitor at Arnold Bloch Leibler, in the firm’s Litigation department.

Since coming to the Bar, Katherine has been briefed to act for a range of regulators, government departments, companies and individuals. Katherine has worked on cases in fora including the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal, the Magistrates’ Court of Victoria, the Supreme Court of Victoria and the Federal Court of Australia.  Her matters have involved (among other things) banking and finance, bankruptcy, insolvency, taxation, intellectual property, health, civil penalties, class actions, professional negligence and corporations law. She has also worked on numerous regulatory and disciplinary matters (both advice and appearance work) involving entities such as the Medical Board of Australia, AHPRA, ASIC, the ATO and the ACCC  She is presently briefed in the Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry.

Katherine has a Bachelor of Laws degree with First Class Honours and a Bachelor of Science degree with a Genetics major, both from the University of Melbourne.  Katherine is also a reporter for the Thomson Reuters Federal Law Reports and Federal Court Reports. Since 2017, Katherine has been a member of the teaching staff at Monash University Law School.

In 2017, Katherine won the award for "Barrister of the Year" at the Lawyers' Weekly Women in Law Awards.

In 2018, Katherine was listed in Doyle's Guide as one of the "Leading Commercial Litigation & Dispute Resolution Junior Counsel".

general.headline: PHD Candidate | Lawyer | RA | Tutor
general.description:
I am passionate about law and gender, and I want to consider the ways in which the law can regulate hate speech. Through my research, I have explored gendered hate speech and its impact on those subjected to it, and the broader impact on society. 

I am also interested in human rights, social justice and international criminal law, and I have a good understanding of these areas of the law via my studies, volunteer experience and my research at La Trobe University.

I completed a Bachelor of Laws/Bachelor of International Relations, and a Diploma of Languages in Spanish in 2015 at La Trove University. I graduated with First Class Honours in Law after completing an Honours thesis on international criminal law and criminal responsibility. During my studies I actively choose electives that reflected my interests, and I sought to increase my understanding of these topics. 

From September - December 2016, I worked in Cambodia at the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia in the Nuon Chea Defence Team. The experience was invaluable and I learnt a lot about trial preparation and criminal procedure.

You can follow me on Twitter: @Nicole_Anne_89

jobs.description:
Similarly to hate crime, hate speech does more than harm the individual victim - it
      ripples through the targeted community, and sends a powerful message of intolerance
      and discrimination to all members of the group to which the victim belongs. In
      Australia, gendered hate speech is pervasive and it has the effect of 'silencing' women,
      and other members of the targeted group, and preventing them from effectively
      participating in civil society. In my PhD I will explore the impact of gendered hate
      
      speech that occurs through various online platforms, including Facebook and twitter.

Tutoring, at a University level, various core law subjects, including Legal Institutions and Methods, Tort Law, Administrative Law & General Research Skills. This includes working as a team to deliver content over a twelve week period and marking students work, including grammar and legal content. 

Researching on a number of important human rights issues, including Minority Rights, International Human Rights, and Gender & the Law. This work has also included co-authoring a number of journal articles.

general.headline: Senior Associate Solicitor at Hartleys Lawyers

jobs.description:
I have worked in a range of different roles in the legal sector. I started my career by moving to Canberra and working as a graduate lawyer in the Department of Finance and Administration. I then gained experience in the Court's by working as a Judge's Associate in the County Court of Victoria and following that, by becoming a duty lawyer at Victoria Legal Aid.  

Since jointing Hartleys Lawyers, I have worked predominantly in the area of family law and honed my skills in the areas of conveyancing and wills. I have also taken to training our up and coming lawyers and I enjoy teaching them what I have learnt so that they can be the best lawyers they can be. 

I am currently the Managing Lawyer of our Fitzroy office and head of Marketing for Hartleys Lawyers. Most of my work is centered around Family Law Property and Children’s disputes. I am an avid advocate and I appear regularly in the Family Court, Federal Circuit Court and Magistrates' Courts around Victoria. I have also appeared in the Supreme Court.  

If you have a legal problem and need some general advice, I am happy to meet with you to discuss a way forward or to discuss any referral networking which is of mutual benefit. 

Please view our website www.hlfamilylawyersmelbourne.com.au 

Have a great day!

Whilst working for VLA, I operated as a duty solicitor in the Frankston, Moorabbin and
      Melbourne courts. This role included providing representation in the areas of crime,
      traffic offences/warrants and Intervention Orders. I would regularly conduct bail
      
      applications, pleas and assess cases on their merits to run to a contest.

In this role, I was governed by the FMA Act and would regularly write regulations for
      agencies to be proclaimed under this act. In addition to this, I would consult with the
      office of legislative counsel in participation of writing legislation and provide memos to
      
      the minister on issues of importance.

general.headline: Associate
general.description:
Admitted to practice in the Australian Capital Territory in 2009, I worked three and a half years as an in-house Senior Lawyer with the Commonwealth Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development in the commercial law and procurement team. I am now an Associate with national commercial law firm, Macpherson Kelley, working out of their Melbourne CBD office in the Corporate and Mergers and Acquisitions team. 

Areas of Expertise
- Business sales and purchases (due diligence and negotiation of sale agreements)
- Commercial contract drafting
- Property leasing
- Liquor licencing 
- Corporations law and compliance
- General commercial law advice

jobs.description:
I provide legal advice on a broad range of commercial transactions and issues with particular focus on corporate law issues, mergers and acquisitions and commercial property leasing.

Areas of expertise:

- Business sales and purchases (including asset sale agreements,  share and unit sale agreements and undertaking due diligence)
- Commercial contract drafting (shareholders’ and other company agreements, securities agreements and distribution agreements)
- Property leasing
- Liquor licencing 
- Corporations law and compliance
- General commercial law advice

Significant Matters:

- The sale of a large Australian automobile sales company to a North American automobile conglomerate. This was a complicated deal, with a sale price of over $40 million, plus millions of dollars in stock, 500 employees and around two dozen properties.

- The takeover by a US automotive parts manufacturer of an Australian/New Zealand automobile parts supplier valued at approximately $16 million.

- The takeover by a European-based health services company of a number of private health facilities across Australia. The sale price included over $2 million in cash and the transfer of ownership to our client of health facilities located in Europe.

Harris Carlson Lawyers practices across a broad range of areas including corporate, franchising, property, commercial litigation, employment law and insolvency and bankruptcy. I worked across all these areas, running matters with limited supervision. 

Areas of Expertise:

- Contract law and drafting, including shareholders’ agreements, loan and securities agreements, distribution agreements, asset sale agreements
- Commercial litigation and dispute resolution
- Corporate insolvency and bankruptcy advice, including recovery action
- Sales and purchase of business transactions
- Property transactions, including land transfers, mortgages, adverse possession and leasing
- Employment disputes

Significant Matters:

- Advice on liability and insurance coverage of a major Australian transport and logistics company following a 2016 cyclone at the Port of Brisbane.

- Ongoing advice to a national car-wash franchisor relating to its franchise agreements, employment obligations, property portfolio management and disputes with franchisees. 

- Negotiation with the Land Titles Office for the removal of "questionable" mortgages over $3 million of commercial property following its forfeiture under Proceeds of Crime legislation.

jobs.companyName: Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development
jobs.description:
I provided legal advice in connection with government procurement, commonwealth financial management requirements, federal airport regulation, aviation and maritime security, major infrastructure projects, local government funding, and vehicle safety regulation. In additional to my commercial role, I conducted litigation before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and provided advice on administrative law matters. My work included contract drafting and administration, assistance in the development of procurement strategies and dealing with Commonwealth property. I also supervised and trained junior lawyers and second counselled the work of my colleagues. 

Significant matters:

- Infrastructure Projects as part of the 2013 Federal Budget
   Drafting of memoranda of understanding between the Commonwealth and State governments for $25 billion of infrastructure projects as part of the 2013 Federal Budget, including the F2M3 Freeway Tunnel, the Brisbane Cross River Rail and the Melbourne Metro Project. I drafted jurisdiction specific terms, set out the funding obligations between the States and the Commonwealth and described the governance arrangements for the projects. 

- Gateway Motorway North
   Drafting conditions as part of a legislative instrument for $1 billion worth of funding being provided by the Commonwealth to the Queensland Government for the construction of the northern section the Gateway Motorway in Brisbane. The conditions related to limiting the Commonwealth’s risk in the project and to prevent the selling of tolling or concession rights connected to the motorway. 

- Aviation services to external territories
  I prepared draft contract documentation as part of a multi-million dollar tender for aviation services to Norfolk, Christmas and Cocos Keeling Islands.

jobs.companyName: Commonwealth Department of Infrastructure and Transport
jobs.description:
As Assistant Director within the Office of Transport Security, my role was to develop and implement government policy to prevent unauthorised infiltration and interference of security-controlled airports, including through acts of terrorism. 
This involved preparation of drafting instructions and explanatory statements for amendments to the Aviation Security Transport Regulations for the enhancement of identity security measures at Australian Airports. I prepared briefings on aviation identity security for the relevant Minister, Senate Estimate hearings and drafted input on behalf of the Department into a Parliamentary Joint Committee into Law Enforcement. In undertaking my work, I regularly consulted with industry and government stakeholders on aviation identity policy and prepared various communications materials for both industry and government.

jobs.companyName: Commonwealth Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations
jobs.description:
I was responsible for implementing and managing a $2.1 billion national partnership agreement between the Commonwealth and state governments for employment training. This included negotiation between the Commonwealth and state governments on changes to training targets, reporting requirements, and funding arrangements totalling $800 million. 
I drafted a number of contract variations in connection with the delivery of the program and developed procedures for executing these variations with over 600 separate training organisations. I was responsible for the management, collation and coordination of the program’s annual report including liaising with state governments and internal stakeholders, as well as the monitoring of training organisation compliance with the requirements of the program services contract. I also had responsibility for taking recovery action against organisations in breach of the program agreement.

jobs.companyName: Commonwealth Department of Communications, Information Technology and Arts
jobs.description:
My role involved the development and implementation of Australian Government policy for landline-based telecommunications, including issues relating to fixed telephone service standards and consumer safeguards, the universal service obligation and the Government’s response to an inquiry into regional telecommunications. I also addressed issues raised by the full privatisation of Telstra.
During my time with the Department, I negotiated and drafted a Memorandum of Understanding with the Tasmanian Government on technology funding arrangements, assisted in drafting a contract for the construction of a $15million research centre in Tasmania and drafted funding guidelines for an $18 million small business seed-funding program.

general.headline: Senior Associate at Mills Oakley
general.description:
Diana Diaz is a Senior Associate in Mills Oakley's Melbourne office working in the area of Workplace Relations, Employment & Safety.

Diana has particular expertise on enterprise agreement making, managing workplace change and restructuring, termination, transfer, remuneration and benefits and business protection.  She has acted for clients of all sizes in a range of industries, including retail, restaurant, fast food and hospitality, medical research, travel, automotive, manufacturing and Government.

Diana advises on all aspects of the bargaining process, including right of entry, pre-approval requirements, drafting enterprise agreements and the approval process with the Fair Work Commission.  Diana has particular experience in advising multi-national employer clients managing change in their Australian operations, including with respect to their employment arrangements, remuneration and benefits and terminations.

She also regularly advises on the employment aspects of mergers and acquisitions including undertaking due diligence audits, preparing sale and purchase agreements, managing redundancies and transfer of employment documentation.

Prior to joining Mills Oakley, Diana worked in the Employment and Labour team at Norton Rose Fulbright.  During that time Diana completed a secondment to the HR team of one of her clients, allowing her to experience the practical realities of providing advice to businesses and understand the day-to-day needs of human resource professionals.

Diana has also previously worked in an immigration law firm and developed an understanding and interest in the complexities arising from engagement of foreign employees, particularly those on 457 visas.

I am also experienced in developing Scope of Work documents for mechanical site based work.

Within a Design role I have developed specification and datasheet’s for various equipment types along with project specific piping systems. Piping design includes design courses in the Fundamentals of CEASAR pipe stress analysis.  I have also developed Pressure Vessels, Tank and Piping design within all relevant Australian standards. I have produced designs for project-specific equipment such as pump and fan designs for process requirements, high-level structural calculations and access platform designs.

I am experienced in interacting directly with clients on site to discuss and plan cut-in’s and shutdowns. 

While on site i have acted in the following roles Site Supervisor and Coordinator of Mechanical Contractors, Weld Inspections, and Quality Control to Australian Standards. This includes supervision across multiple sites that were classified as Hazardous Areas.

general.headline: Partner at HFW
general.description:
Simon deals with shipping and marine disputes, with a focus on the offshore oil & gas sector.

Simon's experience includes issues relating to the construction, chartering, operation and insurance of drilling rigs, FPSOs and FSOs, other surface and subsea installations, and a wide range of offshore support vessels. Simon is familiar with the oil & gas industry, including the LNG sector. He has dealt with incidents offshore, and regulatory issues including pollution, licensing and safety.

Simon has considerable international experience, having advised on offshore projects in Australia, New Zealand, South-East Asia, the North Sea, Brazil and West Africa. He acts in cross-border litigation and international arbitrations, including several large and technical disputes concerning FPSOs and drilling rigs. He also has significant experience in relation to OSV charterparties.

In addition, Simon has broad expertise in maritime law and international trade. He has handled a wide range of shipping cases, including disputes relating to marine casualties, charterparties, shipbuilding contracts, marine insurance, bills of lading and cargo damage, as well as commodity sale and purchase matters. He has represented a variety of domestic and international shipping and trading interests in litigation, arbitration, mediation and commercial negotiations.

Simon has been recognised as a "rising star" in the Doyles Guide for Transport 2016, 2017 and 2018. 

Simon is qualified in Australia and England, and worked for several years in HFW's London office.

general.headline: Director LTAA, Art Market Lecturer, Unit Coordinator & Student Ops (UTAS)
general.description:
Bachelor of Economics & Fine Arts (UTAS), Graduate Diploma of Education (UTAS), Master of Evaluation with Honours (UniMelb), Cert. Art Business (Sotheby's Institute of Art, London).

In 2013 I completed a statistical analysis internship at the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation in Rome. In 2014 I worked in the curatorial team at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, where I was tasked with research, valuations, and assisting in curating. From 2014-2016 I wrote for the UK's leading antiques website, and in late 2015 I finished my Graduate Diploma of Education at the University of Tasmania to enhance my teaching skills, professional skills and development  (public speaking, presentation and ethics). 

In 2014 I founded Lugten-Taylor Art Advisory, aimed at offering professional and unbiased advice to art buyers in Tasmania, mainland Australia, and internationally. I am currently Tasmania's only member of the Art Consulting Association of Australia (ACAA).

In 2015 I commenced work creating a new interdisciplinary breadth unit at UTas which covers a diverse range of disciplines including art, culture, history, business and law. The unit received some of the best unit feedback, 200 students as well as praise for the unit concept, marketing, and new online teaching style. I was also nominated for a Teaching Excellence Award after the first semester offering, and I am currently unit-coordinator and will continue running the unit in semester 1 and 2, 2017. 

In 2016, I became an approved Art Valuer under the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program with the specialist areas of 1870-1900 European Painting and 1900-1950 Australian and European Painting. In 2016 I also worked in administration with International Admissions and Recruitment at UTas whilst finishing my Masters with UniMelb. In 2017 I started working at Foundry as the Cohort & Campus Coordinator managing the Brooke St Pier Campus, students and teachers.

jobs.description:
Through Lugten-Taylor Art Advisory I developed and now lecture and coordinate a new University of Tasmania Breadth Unit called 'The Dark Arts: Culture, Crime, and Corruption'. The unit examines art, culture and heritage through topics such as art theft during times of war, the corrupt black market for art, the history of the art market, and the legal issues associated with intellectual property and ownership of art and cultural heritage. I have led all aspects of this unit's development, including the creation of the unit's concept/idea, the application/proposals, the learning designs, the lecture recordings etc. The unit soon became one of the most popular units with nearly 200 students in the first semester in 2016, and over 400 students in 2017, as well as high levels of engagement and participation, and great student feedback regarding the learning experience.
Through my work in Admissions (Student Operations) at the University, I have developed a strong understanding and interest in the global market for education, and University admissions processes. In October 2017 I attended the Australian International Education Conference (AIEC) to learn more about the Education market (Australia's third largest export) and the different areas of growth and demand internationally.

I lead the Family Law team at Macpherson Kelley, having worked exclusively in Family Law since my admission and completing my Masters in Applied Law (Family Law). 

I thrive on being a trusted ally to people going though hard times, helping them to achieve the best possible outcome and move forward. 

As a team, we are focused on getting our clients the best commercial outcomes for them. Although each matter is individual and we specialise in complex property disputes, I regularly advise on all manner of issues encompassing family law. I formalise agreements and negotiate and resolve disputes. When negotiations aren't fruitful, I litigate. I have run matters including at appeal level before the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia and in the Magellan List of the Family Court. general.headline: Commercial Disputes Lawyer at Lander & Rogers
general.description:
Geraldine is a commercial disputes lawyer who specialises in advising clients in dispute resolution in all Australian jurisdictions.  Her practice covers all aspects of bankruptcies and corporate insolvency, as well as advising in relation to environment / contaminated land and contractual disputes.

Geraldine is a member of the International Women's Insolvency and Restructuring Confederation and routinely acts for liquidators and creditors in a range of insolvency related matters including:
• insolvent trading claims;
• unreasonable director related transactions;
• unfair loans; as well as
• preference payment claims.

She also runs winding up and bankruptcy applications; including substitution applications; in the Supreme and Federal Courts.

Geraldine also has a particular interest in environment / contaminated land litigation, having acted for a global engineering consultancy firm in the Brookland Greens Estate class action and a council in a significant contaminated land matter.  She has also acted for landowners to establish existing use rights for poultry farming and defend claims by a council and residents relating to change of use.

general.headline: Managing Director at QANTM Intellectual Property
general.description:
Leon is the Managing Director and CEO of QANTM Intellectual Property, appointed in August 2016 following listing on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX: QIP).

Prior to this, Leon was the Managing Partner of Davies Collison Cave and Chairman of the firm's national management board.

Leon has extensive experience in the drafting and prosecution, in Australia and overseas, of patent applications for industry and research organisations in the fields of physics and engineering.  He is also experienced in the preparation of patent applications in the areas of fibre optics, lasers, construction, agricultural and earth moving equipment, internal combustion engines and building products. He has also been extensively involved in opposition proceedings before the Australian Patent Office and in infringement actions for enforcement of patents in Australia.

Leon is a past president of the Institute of Patent and Trade Marks Attorneys of Australia (IPTA) having served on its Council from 1992 to 2013. Leon has served two terms on the Advisory Council on Intellectual property (ACIP) to the Federal Government, the second as Chair.

Leon is a Fellow of the International Federation of Patent Attorneys (FICPI) Academy of Education, teaching patent drafting in Europe and a Senior Fellow of the University of Melbourne.

general.headline: Principal at Davies Collison Cave
general.description:
To paraphrase Virgin founder Sir Richard Branson, when your brand or name equates to your reputation, nothing is more important than fighting to protect it. 

I am a trade mark and branding lawyer and registered trade mark attorney. I specialise in trade mark law and brand management. 

My talented team and I help clients identify the signs that distinguish and differentiate their goods and services from their competitors and work to find the most efficient and cost effective way to protect, enforce and defend their valuable trade mark rights. 

Clients appreciate the responsiveness, clarity and commerciality of the advice I provide on brand clearance, the registration of trade marks, trade mark prosecution, oppositions, non-use proceedings and the management of international and Australian trade mark portfolios.

Stuart Green

general.school: Institute of Patent and Trade Mark Attorneys (IPTA)
general.description:
I am a Patent and Trade Mark Attorney with 10+ years of experience and a partner of Halfords IP (HIP).

I can help you to protect your technology and market share using IP rights like Patents, Design registrations and Trade Marks. I have experience working with clients of all sizes spanning individual inventors, universities, small to medium enterprise, and multi-national corporations. 

In particular, I can help with: 
-	Advice on IP strategy
-	Assessing whether your invention may be patentable or suitable for registered Design protection
-	Drafting patent specifications
-	Preparation of Design registrations
-      Filing in Australia and overseas 
-	Assessing the validity of Patents or Design registrations
-	Assessing the risk of infringement of Patents and Design registrations 
-	IP portfolio review and consolidation
-	Technology review and IP identification
-	IP education e.g. seminars or workshops

I have worked with clients in a range of technology areas including:
-	Medical technology, for example, ophthalmic and neurological surgical tools, dialysis devices, and neuromodulation devices
-	Building and construction technology, for example, formwork products, material transport/securement/storage devices, and agricultural fencing
-	Nanotechnology, for example, graphene based devices and cellulose nano fiber (CNF) production
-	Materials technology, for example, concrete recycling and refractory material production 
-	Sporting technology, for example, smart exercise equipment and surfboard fins
-	General consumer technology, for example, adult toys and advertising devices
-	Safety technology, for example, roadside barriers, infant carriers and precautionary vegetation management

Whilst my practice focuses on Patent and Design protection in certain technical areas, our team at HIP have diverse technical backgrounds and cover all areas of IP (including Trade Marks etc.). I can readily direct you to one of our IP specialists as appropriate for your needs.

general.headline: Special Counsel at Marquette IP
general.description:
Fiona has longstanding, extensive experience in trade mark practice ( both Australian and International) including conducting trade mark clearance searches and the preparation and prosecution of trade mark applications in all jurisdictions. Such practice includes prosecution of "non-traditional" trade marks such as colours and shapes. She has considerable expertise in the management of  global trade mark portfolios and has represented large Australian and global companies operating in a wide range of industries, including automotive, petroleum, pharmaceuticals and medical devices, cosmetics, computer software,  fashion, building products, food and beverage, travel and entertainment. 
Fiona has had considerable success in representing clients in connection with numerous contentious trade mark  proceedings in the Australian Trade Marks Office. 
She provides prompt, proactive and commercially focused advice and support in respect of trade mark dispute and infringement issues.
Fiona has held positions with the Victorian and Trans Tasman Intellectual Property Society of Australia and New Zealand and worked on committees for The International Association for the Protection of Intellectual Property.
Fiona is proud to have been included in World Trademark Review's The World's Leading Trademark Professionals every year since 2014, and has been described in this publication as "a shining example who wins plaudits in the non-contentious sphere of trade mark law" and applauded for "skilful portfolio management". 

“For at least the past 15 years, Fiona has serviced BlueScope’s more advanced trade mark requirements (particularly complex filing programs and opposition matters) with prompt, accurate and admirable professionalism – and I have no hesitation in recommending Fiona to any professional trade mark environment where her qualities would undoubtedly be quickly appreciated and valued”  Philip Kennedy (Inhouse Trade Mark Counsel at BlueScope Steel).

general.headline: Principal at Davies Collison Cave
general.description:
I specialise in patent matters relating to chemistry, and in particular materials and polymer science. My main areas of expertise include drafting and prosecution of patent applications, and providing validity and infringement advice.

I have extensive experience in a diverse range of technologies, including polymer synthesis and analysis, bio-polymers, drug delivery, medical devices, tissue engineering, biodegradable polymers, polymer (nano) composites, polymer processing, reactive extrusion, emulsion and suspension polymerisation, free radical polymerisation, RAFT polymerisation, conducting polymers, stimulus responsive polymers, adhesive, coating and packaging technologies, polymerisation catalysts, and carbon technologies including carbon fibre and graphene.

My practice also extends into the fields of organometallic, inorganic and organic chemistry.

Prior to joining Davies Collison Cave, I worked as a senior polymer chemist with Montell (now LyondellBassell) conducting research and development in polymerisation catalyst technology, polymer manufacture, testing and conversion. I also worked as a research scientist at CSIRO where I conducted applied research for several leading polymer manufacturers and converters. I gained further experience as a polymer scientist working as an industrial analytical chemist with ICI Australia (now Orica), specialising in polymer analysis.

general.description:
I am a Partner in the Taxation group at Arnold Bloch Leibler.  I am based in Sydney, Australia.  I have over 20 years experience in taxation law across 3 jurisdictions.  I have been admitted to practice in New Zealand, England & Wales and NSW (Australia).

My goal as a professional is to provide technical expertise to clients, commercially applied and in a confident and approachable manner.  I provide clear and concise advice using plain language - "plain language"​ and "tax" being two terms not often associated with each other.

Specialties: I have extensive experience of the income tax issues associated with mergers and acquisitions, outbound and inbound investments, international finance structures, trust taxation and managing audits and disputes with the Australian Taxation Office. general.headline: Tax Senior Associate at Arnold Bloch Leibler
general.description:
Jonathan Ortner is a Senior Associate  in the firm’s taxation group. Jonathan practices in all areas of direct and indirect tax with a particular focus on the taxation of trusts and corporate income tax, mergers and acquisitions and funds management.

Jonathan has also advised extensively on: cross-border taxation issues; employment taxes, including the tax treatment of employee share schemes, termination payments and fringe benefits; and the GST implications of transactions and dealings in the development of property. 

Using his technical tax knowledge, Jonathan works with clients to obtain commercial and practical outcomes.  He has particular experience in dealing with the Australian Taxation Office on complex tax issues in a dispute resolution context.

Jonathan is a keen and active member of the tax community. As well as presenting on tax topics at various sessions, he has authored and co-authored a number of published articles, papers and bulletins, including Thomson Reuters’ Weekly Tax Bulletin, the Tax Institute of Australia and CCH. Jonathan also sits on the Tax Institute's GST Technical Committee and the SME Committee.

In 2017, Jonathan won 'Emerging Tax Star' in the Tax Institute's "Tax Adviser of the Year" Awards and has recently been named as a finalist in the Lawyers Weekly 30 under 30 awards.

Prior to joining Arnold Bloch Leibler in 2012, Jonathan worked in a financial advisory role at a top investment bank and at a top 4 accounting firm.

Jonathan holds a Bachelor of Commerce and a Bachelor of Laws from the University of New South Wales a Masters of Tax from the University of Sydney.

general.headline: Partner at Arnold Bloch Leibler
general.description:
Paul is the national practice leader of Arnold Bloch Leibler's taxation practice. Paul is a specialist tax lawyer, and has been a partner of ABL since 2001. 

Paul advises a range of clients, including (ultra) high-net-worth individuals, large private groups, public entities and not-for-profits, on Federal tax issues in reviews, audits and disputes, and in domestic and international transactions. With many years' experience in taxation law and administration, including in the Tax Office, Paul has an enviable reputation for representing his clients with dedication, passion and understanding and providing technically astute, strategic, commercially sound and understandable taxation advice.

Paul is recognised in the area of taxation in a number of prominent international and local guides to law firms, including Chambers Asia Pacific, the Legal 500 Asia Pacific, the Tax Directors Handbook, and Doyle’s Guide, in which he was ranked as ‘pre-eminent’ in the category of ‘Leading Tax Lawyers – Victoria,’ in 2016 and 2017.

Most recently, Paul was shortlisted as one of four finalists in the Tax Institute’s prestigious 2018 Chartered Tax Adviser of the Year Award, for a tax professional who has demonstrated entrepreneurial spirit, strategic business expertise and innovative ideas. In June 2018, Paul was named ‘Taxation Partner of the Year’ in the Lawyers Weekly Australian Law Awards.

Paul holds a Bachelor of Commerce from The University of Melbourne and a Bachelor of Laws with first class honours from Deakin University, where he was awarded the Supreme Court Prize. Paul is a Chartered Tax Advisor of the Tax Institute of Australia.  He is a member of the Tax Institute’s Dispute Resolution Committee, the Taxation Committee of the Business Law Section of the Law Council of Australia, and the Executive Committee of the Australian Branch of the International Fiscal Association.  Paul is also a member of the Deakin Law School Advisory Board.

jobs.description: After spending a year at ESIB I realised I needed a new challenge to conclude my final 6 months in London. While still being in Finance, Morgan Stanley enabled me to explore Investment Management. I worked in a fantastic team supporting the head of the Portfolio Solutions Group who encouraged me to work closely with the analysts to gain a better understanding of IM. The knowledge gained allowed me to go beyond the usual EA responsibilites and provide strong trade support. I also had the opportunity to assist in the construction of marketing materials and pitch presentations to new and existing clients. This marketing aspect was of particular interest to me which I enjoyed and hope to do more of in the future.

I joined the Espirito Santo Investment Bank two months after arriving in London. I
      thoroughly enjoyed my time here and am grateful for the opportunity as it opened my
      eyes to the world of Finance. Here I started as a Receptionist before being promoted to
      
      Team Assistant for the Corporate Finance team.

As a Customer Service Representative at Wotif I deal with Wotif.com customers, lastminute.com.au customers and the suppliers (property owners, managers and reservations staff) on a daily basis. 

As each of the websites under the Wotif Group umbrella target a different type of clientele, my position has given me the opportunity to broaden my communication skills to be able to deal with people from a variety of demographics. 

I also have to be able to react promptly to a varse range of problems and queries, most often based on the guidelines and principles that are instructed by Wotif, but also sometimes based on my own personal judgement of each problem and situation. 

I also have to negotiate with customers and suppliers in order to reach solutions that please both parties. Though these solutions aim to be fair, sometimes the outcome is not ideal in the eyes of the customer or supplier which then consequently means I have to deal with complaints. 

The brighter side to my job is helping customers make bookings and hearing their satisfaction when they finally book their romantic getaway, family holiday or even just accommodation for a business trip. By listening to their wants and catering to their needs, it results in the customer being evidently happy and makes my job more fulfilling.

As I have a stong interest in travel, this job is also a great way for me to to discover new interestign places to visit.Customers will ask me to search for accommodation in places that I otherwise would have no idea about, and often if they are local to the area they will give me hot tips on things to do their and history about the location.  

Though this role does not provide me with the opportunity to use my knoweldge in Marketing, it has still allowed me to grow my communication skills and negotiating skills which I feel are valuable attributes in any industry.

As a retail assistant at Sundaze I had to deal with customers face on, listen to their wants in needs in a product (swimwear or beachwear) and supply them with products that I deemed suitable for what they were looking for.

For any consumer, buying swimwear can be quite confronting, intimidating and vulnerable. With each customer, the goal was to make them feel comfortable enough to strip down to their underwear so that we could find the best product to suit their body. This was done by being personable and knowledgable and often by gaining the customer's trust.

general.headline: Lawyer
general.description:
Sahar is a passionate solicitor committed to achieving great outcomes for her clients.

Sahar is admitted as a solicitor of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and the High Court of Australia.  Sahar's qualifications include a Bachelor of Business (Accounting) and a Bachelor of Law and a Graduate Diploma in Legal Practice.

Sahar has a wealth of legal knowledge gained from her extensive experience in both public and private sectors. She has held roles with Legal Aid New South Wales in Local Court Section, criminal law and the family law EIU where she was part of the team responsible for the implementation of the Family Law Early Intervention Programme.  More recently she has worked for the NSW Department of Justice and Attorney General working as an Associate to a senior judge in the District Court of NSW.

Sahar's practice areas include criminal law, family law and litigation and she appears in the Local Court, District Court, Family Court and  Federal Circuit Court.  She combines a compassionate and kind character with exceptional legal skills in order to deliver the best possible outcomes for her clients.

Sahar believes that communication and preparation are the keys to a successful outcome for clients in any matter. Sahar is fluent in a number of languages including Dari, Farsi, Urdu, Hindi and Pashto.

She is an enthusiastic and motivated individual and enjoys meeting different people and constantly developing her knowledge and skills.

general.headline: Research Fellow at Melbourne Law School
general.description:
I am a Research Fellow working on Islamic dispute resolution processes in Australia, a project funded by the Australian Research Council and jointly conducted by The University of Sydney and The University of Melbourne. My current research interests include:
- Religious divorce processes in Western jurisdictions
- Islamic jurisprudence and women's rights
- Contemporary legal reforms in Islamic family law
- Arabic and Islamic Studies curriculum development

I have 20 years experience working with various community organisations across Australia, serving as a founding board member of the Islamic Museum of Australia, and currently on the board of the Australian Muslim Women's Centre for Human Rights in Melbourne. Through these roles, I seek to contribute to building the capacity of Muslim communities in Australia with a particular focus on Muslim women. I also co-founded 'Arabic Made In China', an online Arabic learning platform.

jobs.description:
The Australian Family Law and Islamic Dispute Resolution Processes Project, conducted
      by researchers from The University of Melbourne and The University of Sydney, aims to
      provide the first evidence-based understanding of the experiences of Muslim women
      and men who have used a community process to resolve their family law dispute in
      Australia, along with information about the experiences of imams and professionals
      
      who assist them.

An online Arabic course teaching the Arabic language in an enjoyable, lifestyle format. Duties involve designing curriculum for teaching beginners level Arabic through grammar and conversation as well as useful phrases for various circumstances. I also assist in video production and editing, and respond to and monitor students' progress in learning Arabic.

jobs.companyName: Australian Muslim Women's Centre for Human Rights
jobs.description: The Australian Muslim Women’s Centre for Human Rights is a community welfare organisation established and managed by Muslim women for Muslim women. The Centre was established in 1991 under the name of Islamic Women's Welfare Council of Victoria (IWWCV), as a non-religious organisation reflecting the ethnic, cultural, linguistic and sectarian diversity of Muslim women living in the state of Victoria. In 2010 the IWWCV adopted the new title of Australian Muslim Women's Centre for Human Rights to reflect an increased focus on human rights issues for Muslim women across Australia.

My role at Amanah Islamic Finance involves building key customer relationships with clients in NSW who are looking for Islamic home financing that meets global Shariah standards. With over 20 years of experience working in and with various Muslim community organisations in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide, I am aware of the importance in providing opportunities for Muslims to access Shariah compliant home financing products that are competitively priced, approved by internationally recognised scholars and structured according to Australian commercial and regulatory frameworks.

Taught learn to swim classes to children from 6 month babies through to 10 year olds,
      classes ranged from complete beginners to confident lap swimmers and included
      
      aspects of water safety as well as stroke correction.

An organisation offering advice and mentoring on a range of contemporary issues of
      interest to Australian Muslim women. My role as a board member involves providing
      feedback on various projects and initiatives involving Australian Muslim women,
      
      overseeing grant applications and fund management.

The IMA is a not-for-profit foundation founded in May 2010 with the purpose of establishing the first Islamic Museum in Australia. It aims to showcase the rich artistic heritage and historical contributions of Muslims in Australia and abroad through the display of various artworks and historical artefacts.

As Founding Board Member I assisted in the establishment of the IMA through sourcing reliable information for galleries, keeping supporters updated through the IMA newsletter, meeting and connecting with various stakeholders, presenting at art events and raising awareness of the IMA among academic networks through journal publication. 

Journal reference: Buckley, Anisa. "The First Islamic Museum of Australia: Challenging negative assumptions of Muslims in Australia through art, heritage and discovery", The La Trobe Journal no. 89 (May 2012): 20-35.

Taught the subject 'Women in Arabic and Islamic Literature', offered through the Asia
      Institute. Carried out course coordinator duties including sourcing of resources,
      
      marking assessments and attending to student queries and needs.

Conducted research for my PhD interviewing various stakeholders involved in the

Developed grant applications for leadership courses, assisted in research projects

Taught Years 1-5 Islamic Studies, developed and taught new Islamic Studies curriculum

Developed curriculum and taught at primary and secondary levels in the subjects of

general.headline: Partner at Sparke Helmore Lawyers
general.description:
I am an experienced insurance lawyer focused on property, energy, construction and professional risks across the transport and infrastructure, engineering and construction, power gen and distribution, manufacturing, and agriculture sectors.  I’m routinely instructed to advise on complex coverage issues, defend claims against professionals in the construction sector, assist in crisis and catastrophe management and act in complicated, high-value subrogated recovery and dual insurance actions.  
Experienced in the construction industry as a site manager prior to becoming a lawyer, I can read and interpret plans, understand the complex technical issues and speak the language of insureds, adjusters and experts.  I’m known for my ability to identify the key technical and factual issues earlier than my competitors and concisely explain the legal implications of those issues to clients.  Because of my practical experience the technical learning curve is greatly reduced or even eliminated entirely, which allows me to help clients get to the core issues sooner.  On the claims side this ensures my clients can provide faster outcomes for their insureds and deliver on their claims promise, while on the recovery side it means recovery times are quicker and costs are reduced.

jobs.description:
Sparke Helmore Lawyers is a firm with more than 700 people working from eight offices across Australia, serving the needs of the insurance, government, financial services, technology, mining, construction and property sectors. 
I head up Sparke Helmore’s Property, Energy & Construction team within the Commercial Insurance Group and manage a number of key client relationships across Australia, the UK and the US.  I also work on a number of innovation projects aimed at better using technology to connect and integrate with clients, deliver services more quickly across borders and time zones, and gain efficiencies in document-heavy matters.
I advise insurers on claims under ISR, contract works, construction all risks and professional indemnity policies for insureds operating in the building & construction, engineering, certification, project management, energy, transport and infrastructure sectors. I also possess extensive experience in negligence and misleading and deceptive conduct claims against other professionals including real estate agents and architects.

Lee & Lyons was a specialist insurance law firm based in Sydney. I assisted my clients
      in contentious and non-contentious ISR and design & construction related insurance,
      
      professional indemnity, contract works; CAR and major property damage claims.

Norton Rose Fulbright Australia is one of the largest international legal practices in Australia. I advised mainly Lloyd’s syndicates and UK based company market insurers on professional indemnity claims against design & construct contractors, large engineering consultancies and property developers arising from infrastructure projects and large private developments.

I am a member of the Sparke Helmore management team and am responsible for the successful execution of the Workplace business plan and goals. I am an inclusive leader who strives to empower our national team through adherence to our values, fostering business and financial acumen and celebrating team achievements. 

I am a champion of the Firm’s commitment to Diversity and Inclusion and our Six-Degrees network providing support to and career advancement to our female staff at all levels.
